title: Ototoxic Monitoring: Amikacin-Induced High-Frequency Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I am here for my monthly hearing check-up while I take antibiotics for my lung infection.

problem_summary.onset: Progressive onset during course of antibiotic treatment.
problem_summary.course: Declining sensitivity in high frequencies compared to baseline.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: None reported (no tinnitus or dizziness mentioned).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Likely minimal impact on speech understanding in quiet currently, but potential difficulty in noise or with high-pitched sounds due to high-frequency loss.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Monitoring hearing status to prevent communication handicap during medical treatment.

history.present_illness: Patient is undergoing monthly ototoxic monitoring. She is taking large doses of amikacin for a lung infection (potential duration 1 year). She is also on dialysis.
history.otologic_history: Baseline test showed normal hearing 250-8000 Hz. Pre-existing high-frequency loss (9-16k Hz) was present at baseline but has worsened.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal 250-4k Hz, sloping to moderate SNHL at 6k-8k Hz. Left ear: Normal 250-6k Hz, mild SNHL at 8k Hz. Both ears show significant threshold shifts compared to baseline (e.g., 35 dB drop at 6k Hz in Right ear).

tests.name: High-frequency audiometry
tests.key_findings: Significant progression of hearing loss in the ultra-high frequencies (9k-20k Hz). Right ear shows moderate to mod-severe loss 9k-14k Hz with no response (NR) at 16k-20k Hz. Left ear shows moderate to mod-severe loss 9k-14k Hz with NR at 16k-20k Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent speech recognition ability in quiet, consistent with retained low-to-mid frequency hearing.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes WNL. Left ipsilateral WNL; Left contralateral elevated at 500 Hz. Reflex decay negative where measurable.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity in the low-to-mid frequencies (250-4000 Hz) but exhibits a significant bilateral decline in the high and ultra-high frequencies (6000-20000 Hz) compared to baseline. This pattern is consistent with amikacin ototoxicity. Speech understanding in quiet remains excellent, though the high-frequency loss may impact clarity in noise or music.
counseling_points: Your hearing test today shows a significant change in the high pitches compared to your baseline test.
This change is likely a side effect of the amikacin medication you are taking.
Because of this change, we will communicate with your treating physician to discuss if an alternative antibiotic is possible to prevent further hearing loss.
We recommend using hearing protection if you are around loud noises, as your ears are currently more susceptible to damage.
We will continue to monitor your hearing closely; please return in one month.
notes_for_actor: You are undergoing treatment for a serious lung infection and are on dialysis; you may appear fatigued or physically weak.
You are cooperative but concerned about the potential for permanent hearing loss given your family history.
You do not perceive a major difficulty hearing speech yet, as the loss is mostly in the very high frequencies.
